prompt.p: A 25-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of galactorrhoea. She also describes headaches and irregular periods. She previously describes a regular menstrual cycle, and you note that she has a 1-year-old daughter whom she breast fed for 6 months.
What initial investigation would you perform?

modalFeedback.p: Option C (Prolactin) is Correct. This patient presents with the classic features of a prolactinoma and a prolactin level is essential.
Option A (Full blood count) is Incorrect. The symptoms described are unlikely to be due to infection or anaemia.
Option B (Progesterone) is Incorrect. Progesterone levels are used to confirm ovulation and this investigation is therefore not indicated here.
Option D (Testosterone) is Incorrect. There is no suggestion of virilism or polycystic ovary syndrome. Androgen-secreting tumours do not cause galactorrhoea.
Option E (Thyroid function tests) is Incorrect. Abnormal thyroid function is unlikely to cause galactorrhoea or headaches.
